Posts.Content: I was curious about this type of breast cancer and why is it different, is it more inflamatory or faster spreading, does one take estrogen inhibitors. Just curious. Thanks for your post. On 3/29/2007 Donna1945 wrote: I was diagnosed with metaplastic breast cancer in 2002, and it had spread to 4 of 8 lymph nodes.  I had chemo (A/C & Taxol), and radiation after having a lumpectomy.  (I had a sentinal node biopsy, which suggested that my nodes were clear.  It was wrong.)  So, thank God, I am now a 5 year survivor, against all odds.  My daughter and I started a MBC support group, and we're looking for others who have been diagnosed with this very rare, very aggressive form of breast cancer.  We are a small group of women from all across the US, one in Canada, and one in Budapest, Hungary!  We have also put together a database with our pathology info, treatments, mets info, hospitals and doctors treating us, etc..  We share this with doctors or anyone interested in helping us fight and gain attention to our plight.  We've lost several sisters from this awful disease, and others are in a battle for their lives as I write this. Please leave a message if you are interested in learning about metaplastic breast cancer or are suffering from it, or are someone able to help us.  We're working on a new website that will be up and running very soon.  http://metaplasticbreastcancer.org  . Thank you for your help and interest! Donna

Posts.Title: Mepaplastic breast cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for the post..I see this is in Australia. On 3/31/2007 Suretouch wrote: I would like to alert everyone to some wonderful new technology that is going to help women of all ages, particularly women under 40, with early detection. The technology is FDA approved to "Perform and Document the Clinical Breast Exam" and it is up to four (4) times more sensitive that the human touch. Please support this fantastic new technology so we can all benefit from having a regular "SureTouch" exam. http://suretouch.com.au Many thanks for your kind support Jennifer
Posts.Title: New Hope in Early Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Here is a great website that gives data re Femera being the better way to go these days.  It has been reported in the news as well that many docs are switching as it has proved safer. www.docguide.com/news/content.nsf/news/8525697700573E188525 It gives some interesting reding..CS  On 3/29/2007 Witchdoctor wrote: The current recommendations are for Tamoxifen in premenapausal women and Femara / Arimidex etx for post menapausal.  The  reason is due the the estrogen effect of Tamoxifen , although it sometimes causes problems, is potentially beneficial in some ways.  The Aromatase inhibitors work better in postmenapausal women because their estrogen comes from fat tissue and the the Adrenal gland and aromatase is the enzyme that converts it.  Aromatase inhibitors have their own problems and I have changed more women from these to Tamoxifen because of bone paim than the other way around. The contention that aggressive surgery is a common misperception and goes along with the "more is better" philosophy, which has been shown in many instances and types of cancer., not to be the case.  You would still be put on Tamoxifen or inhibitor no matter what your local therapy is.  If the tumor is large and the breast small and there is no cosmetic advantage then have the surgery.  Both are equal with DCIS.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifin and dysplasia

Posts.Content: Actually it is usually the other way around. Lumpectomyis  as successful as breast removal and maybe more so.  I would google the information.  Also there are better inhibtors than Tamoxifen. Tamoxifen has way too many side effects.Tamoxifen is falling out of favour. Femera is a much safer hormone inhibitor and way less side effects.  Please look this up on the net along with "rates of remission for mastectomy versus lumpectomy" On 3/29/2007 Spiritsquad wrote: If I have dcis and I remove my breast won't I be removing all the dcis hence lessening the chances. See what I have been struggling with is I just have been notified that I need a re excision due to poor margins I have necrosis cells I have solid pattern with high grade on my first biopsy and intermediate grade on the lymphectomy biopsy. I have no great attachment to my breast and my spouse wants me to have it removed to lesson worry of reoocurrance. with reconstructive surgery as an option I guess the thought of removing my breast w/reconstruction and not having to go through more reexcisions (Possibly) and also not having to go through Radiation as well I am not a gambler and from what I have researched so far a masectomy seems the savest route to take. I have yet to read or hear that lumpectomy with radiation and tamoxifen has a better cure rate than masectomy. I have heard that its about the same I guess I am just a littel confused.  Thanks for your answers they are greatly appreciated.  God Bless,  Spiritsquad
Posts.Title: Tamoxifin and dysplasia
